segments.text: So we were down there re-equipping ourselves and getting ourselves sorted out, and you don't do that overnight.

We had to get new replacements in, and remember you've got to check them out and fit them into the crews, and some of them may be trained for artillery, but you're going to use them for tank gunners, and my God, you have to do that in a hurry, and you never get trained people.
to fit every slot where you've had casualties, so you've got to keep training even during battle.
And we got through Thanksgiving all right, and we're still working to put this stuff together when the Ardennes campaign broke out on the 16th of December.
A fellow named Hugh O'Farrell, who had the 2nd Battalion of the 66th Regiment.
I had the 2nd Battalion of the 67th Regiment.
We were ordered out at midnight on the 16th to get in the Ardennes Campaign.
We went on two different columns.
We traveled blacked out all night long over the icy roads, mud, ice, some rain, fog.
Blacked out all night long.
Show you the discipline we had in those units.
We never lost a vehicle.
I never lost a vehicle.
I don't think Hugh lost any.
And we're talking about moving hundreds of vehicles, armored vehicles, fighting units.
Daylight came.
We were on the right road.
We hadn't lost any vehicles.
And we continued to move.
And we got into a place called Sine, Belgium.
I recall we coiled up about two o'clock in the afternoon.
And the division commander had sent word out that the corps commander wanted us to be in Army Reserve.
And this didn't suit the division commander at all, a guy named Ernie Harmon.
What does it mean to be in Army Reserve?
That means you move down here now, you don't do any fighting until I tell you to.
Okay.
Meantime, the division had reconnaissance.
The reconnaissance battalion had gone out
screening all the roads in the area in which the division was going to occupy, which was on the main axis of the Germans to Antwerp.
So we just go grab off that.
What the theater commander and the corps commander are saying is, we've got that armored division to stride their avenue into Antwerp where they're going,
So we know they ain't gonna get there unless they knock that armored division out and ain't anybody about to do that.
That old armored division's got too damn much experience and too much power.
So it was four or five o'clock.
Things began to get a little hazy, you know.
Coming to the road, and this main road, Hugh O'Farrell's on one side of it, I'm on the other side, Bill Whack on the other side.
In other words, we got this major avenue closed, or blocked.
Here came a sergeant up the road with his, from our reconnaissance outpost, with his dead platoon leader laying across the jeep.
in front of the jeep and another wounded man.
And, well, what hit you?
Said, a German column moving up this road.
Said, they knocked out our M8 armored car and they captured and killed the rest of them.
This is all I could get out.
So the story goes that General Harmon contacted the Corps commander and said, here is what's happened.
He said, it's obvious to me that this outfit is moving.
And said, by God, I want orders to attack.
Collins said, you're in Army Reserve and you will
continue to remain in Army reserve and I'll give you orders when you are to attack.
Is this Jay Lawton?
Yeah, Jay Lawton.
Harmon said a four-letter word and then called the two combat commanders
Pee Wee Collier had CCA, he was a brigadier responsible for Hugh O'Farrell, and I.D.
White, who had CCB, who was our brigadier on my side to combat Command B, ordered us into action.
Over Collins Head?
Yeah, over Collins Head.
Told him to go.
You know, F himself.
to be attacking anyway.
He's going to save you a soldier, absolutely.
Well, within the hour, these two leading battalions that led the division down there.
So you took your troops?
We deployed them.
Both of them deployed them on each flank of that road.
Within an hour, here they came, bumper to bumper, just about dark.
Bumper to bumper.
Tanks, about 800 and some odd tanks and armored vehicles and thousands of men.
Second SS Panzer Division.
A whole division?
A whole division.
And what did you have?
How many tanks did both of you have?
I had 56 and you had 56.
What happened?
We destroyed every damn one of them.
Tore them all to hell.
killed thousands of people, their soldiers, and stopped the advance of the Ardennes campaign.
How?
By destruction of that division.
I know.
How did you destroy the division?
With fire, with tank fire and artillery fire and rifle fire.
So you surprised them moving on?
We not only surprised them, but we had the stealth there to kill them with.
Well, once you started shooting, didn't their tanks start spreading out?
Absolutely.
They couldn't spread out.
They were bumper to bumper on this road.
And you had them boxed in on both sides?
We had them boxed in on both sides.
We killed the lead tank and the rear tanks and the vehicles and then just started wading into them.
Well, couldn't the tanks get off the road?
Nope.
They didn't get off the road.
They all burned.
We didn't waitwell, a few of them didn't burn, I guess, but most of them did.
We'd done this before.
This is the third time.
So you had them sandwiched in.
In other words, you had the front and both of the flanks They were just like this.
Here is a road here coming out of the Ardennes campaign.
I mean, coming out of Ardennes.
Some wooded area, lightly wooded area.
I'm on this side here.
Hugh O'Farrell is over here.
Those represent a tank company, and this represents from here to here about 1,000 meters.
And here we are, and they've got these vehicles, one right after the other, real close.
They're moving.
They're moving real close.
I mean, 10 meters between vehicles.
And sometimes less than that.
And people on them and riding in them and so on and so forth.
I'm sure we let some get away.
But we just slapped this one out up here.
And he started hitting in here.
And nobody makes a move.
They try to move off.
Really, you're killing them.
You've got 56 tanks just searching.
And 56 on this side are just busting the hell out of them.
Plus the artillery pounding them.
So it's like a canyon.
Yeah, and we did the same thing.
In which you had control of both sides, and you hit the first and you hit the last tanks, and they couldn't get out of there.
That's right.
What are they going to maneuver against?
Against you?
Direct fire into them?
Mm-hmm.
You see?
We're about 300 to 400 meters off out here.
Oh, that's all you were on both sides?
That's all.
300 to 400 meters, yeah.
My goodness.
We just sucked them in there and killed them.
We did that during the, first time we did that was in St. Louis.
Oh God, the soldiers had a time down there in St. Louis.
Shot up the finance, division headquarters of the finance section and killed a general.
I reported it.
And General Brooks was commanding the division and General White was a brigadier and they wanted to get down there and see this,
dead general.
By the time we got down there, this guy was naked because the soldiers had pulled all his beautiful uniform off, you know.
What are you gonna say?
So they give me hell.
But this headquarter, they had a finance truck in there that got blown up also, and I think somebody said five or six million dollars worth of French francs in there.
Come to find out that
That stuff was for real.
Soldiers were throwing that stuff around all over the place.
Everybody was saying it was no damn good.
Come to find out later, you're about six million dollars worth of gold-certified French francs.
Well, getting back to this and the Ardennes, when you reported what happened, what did General Collins have to say?
Well, there wasn't much he could say.
We just destroyed the division.
I guess after the Ardains campaign was over, General Harmon went home.
So they relieved him?
He didn't go home.
He was promoted to take a corps, a corps headquarters, but he was never given a third star.
So, although he was a thousand percent right, he won the battle, but lost the war.
You know how that goes.
Because he defied Collin's order, but that's where the guy on the ground that knows what's going on, you better listen to him.
Wouldn't it have been a shame if we'd have sat there with that division and allowed these people to come up here and deploy and cut us up?
How do you answer that one?
You don't.
Well, what did you think of Collins?
I thought he was a weak sister.
I thought he was similar to some of the other senior people we had.
They were nice guys.
but not cut out to really fight a war.
And I'm sure that General Collins did thousands of things right, but this was a hell of a mistake.
that he didn't want to accept the division commander's judgment of what the hell was going on.
So, since I was a part of this, you have personal feelings against the guy who, if his orders had not been
countermanded by the division commander, I might not be sitting here.
So you get a personal feel on this thing, which may be good and it may be wrong.
Did you take any prisoners?
I think there were a few.
I think there were a few.
Did you lose any tanks?
We never lost a man, never had a scratch.
I can give you example after example of that in Vietnam.
We're going to get to Vietnam later.
Where firepower saves people's lives.
Let's go back now to discuss, well we just finished the Ardennes and let's continue on that campaign.
During the Ardennes campaign, I was wounded again, I guess for the second or third time.
I was evacuated back to England.
What kind of wound was it?
It came from German artillery.
I had my head outside the tank trying to see and try to move through the woods.
And wooded areas are not very conducive for tank operations, but if that's what you got, that's what you use.
And the German artillery breaking in the trees with tree bursts, they cut this finger off and cut it down.
So they were shooting above you with fragment shells and spraying you.
You see, it was point detonating fuse and it would be hitting in the trees and going off in the trees and the fragments were coming down.
So, your hand and glove was laying outside the turret, you know, and you're trying to move along and conduct a battle and it cut this thumb and finger off.
It's got some use left in it, but anyway,
About that time my gunner took a piece inside the head and killed him and I went down then.
The loader went over to become the gunner and I dropped down in the tank to load the gun and a round came in and
kind of anti-godling, 75 millimeter round, came in the tank and bounced around in a turret and pinned this arm against the wall.
And I had on a heavy leather flying jacket, wool lined, or this arm would have been totally knocked off.
And that anti-tank projectile, tungsten steel that they were shooting broadsided against it after it had been around, lost most of its velocity, but pinned it against the turret and dropped down.
So I just totally lost all this, you see.
From your elbow down, you had no feeling whatsoever.
Yeah, not at all.
And this was cut open, and thank God it was cold, you know, and the blood had been coagulating in my leather glove, which had a liner in it.
And this anti-tank shell went right through them?
Came through off of the angle.
Right through, right into the tank?
Right into the tank, yeah.
And, uh,
So I would find No one was killed?
Only my gunner who was killed from the Shrapnel.
Not shrapnel, shell fragment.
Shrapnel, you know, is a ball.
Right, right, okay.
Okay, so don't you consider yourself and your crew pretty lucky that the shell could purse right into your tank and not kill anyone?
Yeah, it came in behind the driver.

and it was kind of low, and they came in, and they come up, and they, my gunner was already dead, and he had slumped over, and we were trying to continue the battle here because we were receiving a lot of pressure, and as long as we shoot, it was all right.
It hadn't, a shell fragment hadn't hurt the tank, and he was still in good
loading the damn thing, and the loader moved over to be the gunner.
And the Germans were up in front of you on the road?
Oh, yeah.
They were anti-tank guns.
Yeah.
And you were on the lead.
75mm, yeah.
And so you were the first one to get hit?
I was the first one to get hit.
And so what'd you do then?
Well, people moved up.
How'd you maneuver the tank down?
I was still on the radio and people moved up.
A guy named Jim Starr, who had my F company, I told him, I said, Jim, move up on the left here and get through these woods as best you can.
Get up here and get on the left here and take this damn fire off of us.
I said, I've been hit and you're going to have to take command.
He said, Roger that, I understand.
So he started moving.
bypass my dead tank, of course, you see.
I was dead in the water.
The tank was finished.
So, the driver was able to get out and get the dead sergeant out and with a loader help get me out and
tank for some reason didn't blow up until we were a hundred yards away from it.
I don't know what happened.
I don't know whether they shot it and hit it again or what happened, but we were getting away from it because you never know when a fire is gonna start.
So you were moving back up the road?
They were out.
We were, they were carrying the dead soldier and I was making it on my own.
So Jim Starr was in charge.
He assumed command.
And so did Starr and the rest of the tanks, did they knock out these?
Went ahead and cleaned them out.
Outflanked them then?
Outflanked them, come in on the flank of them, killed them, and I just stopped them.
And I was evacuated to Paris and then to England.
And I was gone about three or four weeks total time.
Came back, Ardennes campaign, I was hit on, I believe it was the first or second of January, and the campaign was over on about the 13th.
Second Army Division moved up north of Hawkin, and
I stole away from the hospital.
I went AWOL from the hospital and went to England.
I went to Heathrow, caught an airplane to Orly Field in France, hitchhiked into Paris, went to the rear area transportation and asked for transportation to go back up to the front.
Ended up by riding with a black sergeant who was leading a red ball truck company up that night.
We left at midnight.
We spent all night and got into the edge.
When I got into the edge, I got the field telephone of one of the units there, one of the supply units.
And I called on the line at division rear headquarters.
I got the headquarters.
My battalion sent a jeep for me and picked me up in Liege and I was back in my outfit in command.
Why'd you go AWOL?
Why didn't you wait until you got orders?
I was afraid I might lose my unit, you know, if you'd gone very long.
You're gone more than 30 days until I would get another guy to command your unit.
What were you gone?
Three weeks?
I'd gone about three weeks.
Did the doctors want to keep you there?
They wanted me to keep me on.
As a matter of fact, they threatened to send me to the United States, and I didn't want any part of that.
So I How was your arm by that time?
Well, I was doingthis is still, you know, it's just dead out there.
It's just there, but it's better than nothing.
Good thought.
Yeah, and it hadn't healed up, of course.
But it was coming along, no infection.
It moved the stitches out of it.
And how was the rest of your arm?
Well, this was still black, and they were having me put it in.
They were working it every day, a physiotherapist.
It got to where it didn't hurt me any, but you know, it's still black from where it got squashed.
So I decided that I could make it, and I just got out of there.
Did you think about your career at that time?
Yeah, that's what I was thinking about.
I didn't want to lose my command.
I didn't want to lose my unit and the war wasn't over.
But going AWOL, that certainly might not help your career in the long run.
Well, that's true, but I just had to take a chance on that.
I just had to take a chance on that.
And you were just eager to get back in the combat?
I wanted to get back in my unit.
In your command.
In my command, so...
I never thought much about my career then.
I was just thinking about my unit and trying to stay alive, you know.
And so when you got back, what did your commanding officer have to say?
Oh, my God, he was happy as hell.
Oh, he was?
Yeah.
Did you tell him that you went over the hill?
I told him that I'd had transportation between
London and Paris were such, and the hospital, that I didn't have time to check out.
So if there's any complaints, it's because I just didn't have time to really go through all the procedure of checking out.
You've got to understand what you did.
Well, did you ever, never heard a word?
Never heard a word from it.
So what, did your commanding officer cover for you then?
Nothing ever come up.
I guess that...
The doctors never did anything?
Never did a thing, no, no.
I don't think they really cared, you know.
The guy would get up and leave.
They don't know where in the hell he goes.
Soldiers do the same thing.
There were soldiers noted for running off from the hospital and getting back to his unit.
He doesn't want to go join anybody else's unit.
He doesn't want to get in that replacement system, you know.
So he'll find out that he's gonna be assigned to what he called a REPL depot, replacement depot, you see, where you're a number and you're just gonna go here or wherever they need you most.
Well, you just leave the damn hospital and go AWOL and go back to your unit.
When you tell them that, just tell them that you're alright and you want to get back to your unit.
You don't want to go to somebody else's unit.
How had your command done while you were away?
They had done well.
Jim Starr had, from Gainesville, Texas up here, he had

He had taken over command of the battalion, he was a captain, taken over command of the battalion and finished off the campaign and then moved the unit up there and they were getting ready to go again and I walked in there a couple of days before.
He stepped back down to his company and took it over and off we went.
We headed out then to the Rhine, I guess.
And I took a town named Krefeld, K-R-E-F-E-L-D, Krefeld on the Rhine.
And that was the industrial center in the industrial area.
Germans mostly, most all of them except some remnants, had pulled back across the Rhine and blown most of the bridges.
I had tried to get this bridge at Krefeld, but they had blown that thing a few hours before I got there.
We found out later that there was a failure on the Germans' part down south where the 9th Armored Division crossed.
I believe that's what it was.

But we pulled up against the Rhine and first thing you know we get orders to cross at Wessel, W-E-S-S-E-L, and they had an airborne drop over there, about a regimental strength airborne drop over there.
on the other side while we were bridging it.
We bridged, the 2nd Armored bridged to Ryan the vessel in eight hours and 20 minutes.
Eight hours and 20 minutes at dark, after dark.
That's 17th Combat Engineers of the 2nd Armored Division.
Eight hours and 20 minutes.
And I crossed them.
And I was the lead element, advance guard for the division.
And I headed for Liebstadt and Paderborn, and the 3rd Armored Division crossed down at Cologne.
And that division was commanded by Maurice Rose.
He was killed.
Mike Gilman, who
was there.
Their advance guard leader was killed.
I never lost a soldier on the north flank in my unit.
I fought like hell.
Mike Yeoman is a brother of the football coach at the University of Houston.
I can't think of a yeoman down there's name, first name now.
I can't think, it doesn't matter.
But we finished off after five days and five hard nights of, we met at Paderborn, linked up.
That's the heart of Germany, that's still the heart of Germany.
Whoever takes that has Germany.
I was going to, I had a great disappointment.
I was going to, I promised the soldiers, I said, we get this link up here, we closed off some fourteen divisions, and the whole heart of Germany.
Great double envelopment, historical double envelopment.
as it was a historical meeting engagement back on the 16th of November.
I had promised my soldiers that they'd get a chance to get some rest and we'd get all of our vehicles refueled and maintenance up on them and ammo and all that.
All of that was underway.
We had coiled up in a big area.

big wagon train area, tank battalion, tank battalion, tank battalion, infantry battalion with each tank battalion, artillery in the middle ready to shoot in any direction, scout reconnaissance out all the way around.
We brought in fuel and ammunition and some food and water and that sort of thing.
The mail, which they hadn't seen.
And we were gonna get all that maintenance done and then we were gonna
good night's rest for the first time.

We met those people about two o'clock in the evening and we were about finished about five o'clock and it's beginning to get gray and dusk and soldiers were thinking about going to sleep when here comes the division commander.
Who was he?
General, now General I.D.
White.
a retired four-star general now, Norwich graduate, Norwich.
So.
Was he a one-star general then?
Two.
He'd just been promoted to two-star.
Ernie Harmon left after the Ardange campaign and he took over the division and got promoted.
What did General White have to say?
General White said, you've got your map?
Yes, sir.
He said, we're right here.
I said, that's right, sir.
He said, well, I want you to move from this point up here.
I said, hell, that's 12 kilometers up there.
That's right.
Well, he said, I want you to jump off here at midnight, and the division is going to follow you by six hours.

And I want you to get a pass through the Teutoburger Wall at a town named Dentmole, and that's a SS collecting point where all the soldiers, SS soldiers that get, units get beat up and so on and forth, they all
They were reorganized into other units.
He said, I want you to take that pass and that mall and have that all cleared out because the whole division is going to follow you by six hours.
You're going to jump off at midnight, and we're going to start moving at six.
Goddamn.
I said, my soldiers haven't had any rest or anything.
He said, say again, once you're here at midnight, the division's going to follow you by six hours.
And I said, roger that.
So I called Lieutenant Drake, who had the reconnaissance company that was attached to me.
I said, Drake, five o'clock.
here at midnight.
I get some scouts quick on the goddamn road and understand that this is an uncleared area.
Uncleared.
So the enemy could be right there?
The enemy could be all over it, you understand that?
He said, Roger, sir, and I said report to me every 30 minutes by radio.
Roger that.
He said, I'll send Sergeant Happy.
Sergeant Happy got killed the next day.
No, two days later, but he said, okay.
Sergeant Happy was replacing a lieutenant because he didn't have enough lieutenants in reconnaissance, so he took a reconnaissance platoon.
Sergeant Happy took off and he reported, and Break, Lieutenant Break, a company commander, was following back behind, moving along, posting some guides.
very helpful that night.
If you got to be at some place at some specific point at that time, you got to know where you're going.

Well, everything worked well, and I got on that damn thing, and I figured we were going to have to move about 10 o'clock, and I didn't want to stop, but by the time we got the orders out, and everybody zeroed in, and so on and forth, it was, we didn't have any spare time, so we started moving in,
and got up here a few minutes ahead of time, and I just proceeded to continue to move.
We ran into Army headquarters during the night.
German?
Germans.
We caught German tank crews with tanks guarding the road that we were on asleep.
They were exhausted too.
Yeah, and we used the old piano wire method, you know.
Do you know what I'm talking about?
Take a piece of piano wire about
three feet long.
You put a hand grenade ring on each end of it that fits in your finger.
A hand grenade ring, you know, it pulls the piano out of your hand and it's very strong.

And so, you catch a guard out there halfway asleep or something, or asleep on the ground, you just put that piano wire over there and cross it and pull it up on his neck, you know, and you can kill him without him ever making a squawk.
and that's what you have to do.
So we did the lead elements.
I was with the lead recon platoon all night, everybody moving along.
Ran into this headquarters.
I called back on the radio to my rear area.
So you were in the lead?
I was up front.
You were in the lead jeep then, or you were in the lead tank?
I was in the lead jeep behind the recon platoon.
Okay, and the recon platoon, what did they have?
Jeeps.
Yeah, jeeps, that's all.
All jeeps, yeah.
And you guys were driving up and catching these guys asleep?
At night.
Or were you walking up?
At night.
They were so tired that they didn't even hear you driving up?
No.
You know, a jeep's fairly quiet.
We come into an area that you just, obviously, you know, there's some activity here.
You can see some lights flickering over there.
That's not German houses because the Germans would shoot them, you know.
That's the military.
So we ran into this one army headquarters and it was about 300 yards off the road.
The tank crews on guard there were asleep.
We knocked them off.
Would you have 50 calibers on the Jeep?
50 calibers.
50 calibers or 30 calibers.
Usually a 30 caliber is mounted down there, but sometimes you have a pedestal mount with a 50 caliber up there because it gives you some pretty heavy stuff.
And we use armor-piercing rounds in it too to clean up thin-skinned vehicles and stuff.
Anyway, this is obviously the big headquarters.
They had generators running, you know, and lights and tents, and you could see them flickering in and out and so on and forth.
And I called back and said, at this point, you're going to find a tank there, but don't worry about it.
The crew is dead, and it's right opposite an Army headquarters here, or headquarters of that magnitude, because it had about
We were able to identify there about 10 or 15 big Buick sedans, Mercedes and Buick sedans, so that's typical.
A little parcel of land I paid $900 an acre for and selling it for $2,500.
Really?
Where's that?
Down in the old country in Kerr County, north of San Antonio.
Gee, that's too bad.
Well, I'll tell you what.
Ms. H., since I had this cancer, she's a little upset about us having properties in Montana and South Carolina.
You were discussing moving in.
to the German headquarters and you were radioing back.
Yeah, well during that night we ran through all types of different installations.
And you got to this German headquarters and now you were radioing back.
Yeah, I was radioing back telling them you had to keep everybody advised and up to date because you didn't want some tank driver coming along there that might be

inclined to be frightened and see this German tank there and start shooting and create a disturbance in your rear area or the middle of your element when you're using as much stealth as possible during the night and being as careful as you can because you

The one thing that worries you most, I think, during the night, movement and fighting during the night, is that you keep track of where you are because you don't want to be on the wrong road the next day when a division is following you and you've cleared one road, but it just so happened that you were on the wrong road and they're going on another road that hasn't been cleared.
So that's disaster.
So that's what I think you worry about most of during the night.
But anyway, I had a funny thing happen there.

I called my headquarters commandant in the rear of my column, and I said, when you pass this particular area here, I said, I'd like for you to, since you're at the rear of the column, the combat elements, I said, I'd like for you to shoot up these damn Buick sedans in this Army headquarters over here.
Did you already capture the headquarters?
I had already captured it, but I said that.
And who was in there?
Were there some officers?
Well, they were running.
Oh, hell, they were running off.
Most of them run off on us.
We didn't get a handful of them.
We got a few soldiers.
But you drove in there in your Jeeps.
Well, reconnaissance elements went in.
And you tried to surprise them?
Hell, they were running out all through the dark on us every place.
And so I just called a guy, a captain back there at my headquarters, a commandant, and I said, when you get up here, blow this stuff up.
I said, there's 15 or 20 Mercedes Buick sedans up here.
High officers ran off and left them, and they're in the woods out here somewhere.
I don't know where they are, so you may have a fight when daylight comes, but when you come along here, shoot them up.
About that time, on the radio, it said, Python White 6, this is Pyramid 6.
I said, Roger.
He said, disregard your last instructions.
Disregard.
He said, I've been looking for a Buick sedan for three years.
I said, I called my commandant and I said, disregard my last transmission.
Old Captain come back and said, Roger, sir, we are in receipt of message.
Goddamn, they did.
They drove around, you know, they got them some staff cars.
1940 Buicks, I think they were, Mercedes.
Well, a very interesting thing, we proceeded on during the night and we got
